subject: Photography
title: Photography and Civil Rights
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Photography and Civil Rights.

hook.text: Images of fire hoses aimed at children. Dogs attacking peaceful marchers. Photography made injustice undeniable.

buildup.text: The U.S. Civil Rights Movement was one of the most photographed social struggles in history.

discovery.text: Gordon Parks and Ernest Withers documented the movement, creating images that galvanized widespread public support.

twist.text: These photos didn't just document change ‚Äî they caused it. Visual evidence made denial of injustice impossible.

climax.text: Photography gave the Civil Rights Movement a visual language that transcended barriers of geography and literacy.

punchline.text: You can deny words. You can't deny a photograph.

quiz.question: How did photography contribute to the Civil Rights Movement?
options: Images made injustice visually undeniable and galvanized public support
